thread.title: BMC elections 2017: N Chandrasekaran to Deepak Parekh, VVIPs queue up to cast votes
thread.title_full: BMC elections 2017: N Chandrasekaran to Deepak Parekh, VVIPs queue up to cast votes

author: FE Online
title: BMC elections 2017: N Chandrasekaran to Deepak Parekh, VVIPs queue up to cast votes
text:
BMC elections 2017: N Chandrasekaran to Deepak Parekh, VVIPs queue up to cast votes BMC elections 2017: N Chandrasekaran to Deepak Parekh, VVIPs queue up to cast votes The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) officials had appealed to the people of Mumbai to come out in large numbers and cast their vote, as each vote counts. By: FE Online | New Delhi | Published: February 21, 2017 9:17 PM Shah Rukh Khan also turned out to cast his vote. (ANI) 
BMC elections 2017: BMC elections 2017: Voting for the Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) polls was held today. By teh closing time, the poll percentage was 52.17 per cent. That show half the voters did not exercise their franchise, which under democrcy, is nothing short of a sin. However, that was not the course of action adopted by some of the busiest corporate chiefs in the country. The busiest of them all would surely have been none other than N Chandrasekaran, the new chairman of Tata Sons, who took over the reigns from veteran Ratan Tata today. He cast his vote today, prioritising it above all his professional engagements; including the taking over as the chairman of country’s largest business house. 
Popularly known as Chandra, the new Tata Sons’ chairman was spotted with inked finger at the Bombay House after completing the first board meeting; as the chairman of the USD 103-billion salt to software empire. Most of the news from Mumbai came from the polling booths today, as the western metropolis is geared up to elect a new civic body for BMC – the richest municipal corporation body in Asia! 
You may also like to watch this video : 
Apart from the Tata Sons chairman, other corporates seen at the voting booths were HDFC chairman Deepak Parekh and Keki Mistry, chairman. Godrej Group’s Adi Godrej and chairman of the Hiranandani group, Niranjan Hiranandani were also seen at polling booths in South Mumbai. Tina Ambani also cast her vote at a polling booth at Colaba this morning, reports PTI. 
Among the bankers, State Bank of India’s (SBI) chairperson Arundhati Bhattacharya also cast her vote. 
The Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC) officials had appealed to the people of Mumbai to come out in large numbers and cast their vote, as each vote counts. Traditionally, BMC has a poor track record of lesser turnouts during Civic polls. The voting percentage in the last two polls, ie. 2007 and 2012 were 42 and 45 per cent respectively. 
Going by figures, the BMC has 227 corporators, for which 2,275 candidates are vying for. It was also reported that the election authorities have set up 7,304 polling booths in 1,582 centres across Mumbai. 
Post-elections, the counting of votes will be taken place on February 23. Please Wait while comments are loading...
